arm_group.description: neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the quadriceps muscle with kneehab
neuromuscular electrical stimulation of the quadriceps muscle with intensity which causes no visible contraction or displacement of the leg (activation below motor threshold)

brief_summary.textblock:
The main aims of the study are (1) to examine the impact of contralateral strength training
      on the quadriceps muscle function after ACL surgery and (2) to compare the magnitude of
      cross-education induced by NMES versus eccentric strength training.

clinical_study.brief_title: Contralateral Strength-training After Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Reconstruction

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  patients scheduled for ACL reconstruction surgery

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Concomitant lower limb injury or disorder

          -  previous lower extremity open surgery on the contralateral lower limb

          -  cardiac disease

          -  pregnancy

clinical_study.official_title: Could Contralateral Quadriceps Strength Training Attenuate the Strength Loss in the ACL-operated Knee?

primary_outcome.measure: Change in bilateral quadriceps muscle strength [Nm]

reference.citation: Feil S, Newell J, Minogue C, Paessler HH. The effectiveness of supplementing a standard rehabilitation program with superimposed neuromuscular electrical stimulation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction: a prospective, randomized, single-blind study. Am J Sports Med. 2011 Jun;39(6):1238-47. doi: 10.1177/0363546510396180. Epub 2011 Feb 22.
Hortobágyi T, Scott K, Lambert J, Hamilton G, Tracy J. Cross-education of muscle strength is greater with stimulated than voluntary contractions. Motor Control. 1999 Apr;3(2):205-19.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in self-reported questionnaire outcomes (KOOS, WOMAClk)

secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of present functional status by means of hop tests

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
